p: Five of the 10 climatically extreme years (1978/1979, 1985/1986, 1989/1990, 1994/1995 and 1995/1996) did not coincide, with or without lag, with any of the consensus population change years in either Lepidoptera or birds. Given that extreme events tended to happen in different years for Lepidoptera and birds ( figure 2 d), it is possible that other taxa responded strongly in these years. The pattern of apparently mixed responses is also exhibited by individual species. For example, the mottled grey moth Colostygia multistrigaria population crashed after the 1976 drought, but not after other dry years, and the tree sparrow Passer montanus declined in association with some, but not all, cold winters ( figure 1).
